G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, such that this Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the causes of action arose in Suffolk County and the incident occurred at 1234 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 3..proposition: Defendant conducts substantial business in Suffolk County and, on information and belief, maintains continuous and systematic contacts with Massachusetts sufficient for the exercise of personal jurisdiction under G.L. c. 223A, §§ 2, 3.

G.L. c. 89.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a safe, prudent, and lawful manner, in compliance with the Massachusetts motor vehicle and bicycle laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85, § 11B.

G.L. c. 90.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a safe, prudent, and lawful manner, in compliance with the Massachusetts motor vehicle and bicycle laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85, § 11B.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B..proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a safe, prudent, and lawful manner, in compliance with the Massachusetts motor vehicle and bicycle laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85, § 11B.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (\u201cNo person s.raw_text: G.L. c. 90, § 14 (“No person shall open a door on a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists…”).
G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (\u201cNo person s.proposition: Massachusetts law requires the operator or passenger of a motor vehicle to exercise due care when opening a door into an area where traffic, including bicycle traffic, may reasonably be expected, and prohibits opening a vehicle door unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with other traffic.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under the Massachusetts comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff’s contributory negligence, if any, does not bar recovery so long as the plaintiff’s negligence is not greater than the total negligence of all defendants, and any damages are diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s degree of fault.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B..proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

*Coombes v. Florio*, 450 Mass. 182 (2007.proposition: In Massachusetts, a driver of a motor vehicle owes a duty of reasonable care to all foreseeable users of the roadway, including bicyclists using marked bike lanes.
*Coombes v. Florio*, 450 Mass. 182 (2007.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Coombes v. Florio contains only the per curiam disposition reversing summary judgment and noting separate opinions by several justices. It does not discuss motor vehicle duties, roadway users, or bicyclists, nor does it articulate any rule about a driver’s duty of care to foreseeable roadway users. Based on the text given, this case cannot be said to support the specific proposition about drivers’ duties to bicyclists in Massachusetts.
*Coombes v. Florio*, 450 Mass. 182 (2007.relevant_excerpt: “The judgment of the Superior Court granting the defendant’s motion for summary judgment is reversed. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings.”

*Grenier v. Town of Shrewsbury*, 13 Mass.raw_text: *Grenier v. Town of Shrewsbury*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 103 (1982).
*Grenier v. Town of Shrewsbury*, 13 Mass.proposition: In Massachusetts, a driver of a motor vehicle owes a duty of reasonable care to all foreseeable users of the roadway, including bicyclists using marked bike lanes.
*Grenier v. Town of Shrewsbury*, 13 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning law and the timeliness and jurisdictional requirements for judicial review of decisions by a board of appeals under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 40A. It does not address tort duties of motor vehicle drivers, roadway users, or bicyclists, nor does it discuss reasonable care or bike lanes. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the stated negligence proposition.
*Grenier v. Town of Shrewsbury*, 13 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The question for decision in this case is whether a ‘person aggrieved’ within the meaning of G. L. c. 40A, § 17 … is entitled to judicial review of a decision of a board of appeals by which it expressly grants a petition for a variance if that person files a complaint for such review within twenty days of the date when the board files a copy of its decision with the city or town clerk but more than twenty days after the date when the board has constructively granted the petition…”

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990);
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: A violation of a safety statute such as G.L. c. 90, § 14 is evidence of negligence.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the effect of statutory violations on negligence and reiterates the Massachusetts rule that violation of such a statute is not negligence per se but is only some evidence of negligence. Although the statute discussed is G.L. c. 138, § 69 rather than G.L. c. 90, § 14, the court states the general principle applicable to ‘a statute such as § 69,’ making the case good authority for the broader proposition that violating a safety statute is evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: A violation of a safety statute such as G.L. c. 90, § 14 is evidence of negligence.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in Massachusetts, violation of a statute does not constitute negligence per se and, without an existing common-law duty, statutory violations do not themselves create tort liability. While statute violations may be relevant, the court here uses the principle to reject the argument that violations of alcohol-related statutes independently establish civil liability. Thus, the case undermines rather than supports the proposition that violating a safety statute like G.L. c. 90, § 14 is evidence of negligence in the sense of establishing duty or negligence per se.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

*Pace v. City of Boston*, 95 Mass. App..raw_text: *Pace v. City of Boston*, 95 Mass. App. Ct. 1107 (2019) (Rule 1:28 decision recognizing protections for cyclists).
*Pace v. City of Boston*, 95 Mass. App..proposition: Under G.L. c. 85, § 11B, bicyclists have the right to use public ways and are entitled to the same rights and subject to the same duties as drivers of motor vehicles, with additional protections afforded to them as vulnerable road users.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Massachusetts common law of negligence requires proof of (1) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, (2) breach of that duty, (3) causation, and (4) damages.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between breach and damage. This matches the proposition’s four elements (duty, breach, causation, damages), so the citation accurately reflects the opinion’s statement of the negligence standard.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Massachusetts common law of negligence requires proof of (1) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, (2) breach of that duty, (3) causation, and (4) damages.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements the plaintiffs must prove for negligence, but it omits duty as a separate, explicit element and instead frames the burden as breach of duty, actual loss, and causation. It cites the Restatement and a treatise, but does not clearly state the four-element formulation (duty, breach, causation, damages) that the proposition claims for Massachusetts common law. Thus, the case does not squarely support the specific four-part proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147;.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to actions that create a foreseeable risk of harm to others, and “foreseeability” is a central component of the duty and causation analysis.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147;.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, and that a precondition to this duty is that the risk of harm be recognizable or foreseeable. It further emphasizes that foreseeability is analyzed both in defining the existence and scope of duty and, separately, in the jury’s causation analysis, directly aligning with the proposition that reasonable care extends to conduct creating foreseeable risks and that foreseeability is central to duty and causation inquiries.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147;.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … ‘To the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty… it is a test of the “reasonable foreseeability” of the harm.’”}

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to actions that create a foreseeable risk of harm to others, and “foreseeability” is a central component of the duty and causation analysis.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion expressly agrees that the dispositive question is whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the "reasonably foreseeable risk of harm" created by the defendant’s negligence, tying duty/causation to foreseeability of harm. Although the excerpt is from a concurrence and focuses on disagreement about causation doctrine and prior cases, it endorses foreseeability as central to the negligence analysis in this case, which is consistent with the proposition. The duty and causation analysis is framed explicitly in terms of reasonably foreseeable risk of harm.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.raw_text: *Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.*, 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986);
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.proposition: Under the doctrine of respondeat superior, an employer or principal is vicariously liable for negligent acts of its employee or agent committed within the course and scope of employment or agency.
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.case_name: Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.support_reasoning: The court explicitly frames its respondeat superior analysis in terms of when an employer is liable for an employee’s tortious conduct within the scope of employment. It then applies traditional scope-of-employment factors (kind of act employed to perform, within time and space limits, and motivated at least in part to serve the employer) and concludes that, because the employee’s wrongful conduct was within that scope, it was legally the employer’s conduct and the employer is responsible for the resulting losses. This directly affirms vicarious liability for negligent or wrongful acts committed in the course and scope of employment/agency.
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.relevant_excerpt: “To determine whether an employee’s conduct is within the scope of his employment for purposes of employer liability under G. L. c. 93A, we may appropriately be guided by a consideration of the factors relevant to scope of employment determinations bearing on the imposition of vicarious liability on employers for the tortious conduct of their employees…. [C]onduct of an agent is within the scope of employment if it is of the kind he is employed to perform…; if it occurs substantially within the authorized time and space limits…; and if it is motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer…. As a result, our case law compels the conclusion that Joseph’s participation in the termination of Post’s contract was within the scope of his employment, that Wang is legally responsible for the losses incurred by Post and BI….”}

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.raw_text: *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002).
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.proposition: Under the doctrine of respondeat superior, an employer or principal is vicariously liable for negligent acts of its employee or agent committed within the course and scope of employment or agency.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.support_reasoning: The court expressly frames respondeat superior as making an employer vicariously liable for torts of its employee committed within the scope of employment and applies that rule to physician employers. The opinion states that, once an employment relationship is established, the only remaining issue is whether the allegedly negligent act occurred within the scope of employment. This aligns directly with the proposition that an employer or principal is vicariously liable for negligent acts of its employee or agent committed within the course and scope of employment or agency.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment. … To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. … ‘An employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’”

*McMurdo v. Getter*, 298 Mass. 363, 365\.proposition: A rideshare company that organizes, controls, and profits from the transportation services provided by its drivers may be held liable for the negligence of those drivers in performing the company’s business.
*McMurdo v. Getter*, 298 Mass. 363, 365\.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether an unlicensed optical business can lawfully practice optometry by employing a licensed professional; it does not address tort vicarious liability for negligence in providing transportation services. While the court does characterize the physician as a “servant” of the optician defendants, this is in the context of regulatory/professional-licensing law, not respondeat superior for accidents. The opinion provides no discussion of a company’s liability for its agents’ negligence in performing transportation or analogous services, so it does not support the specific rideshare-liability proposition.
*McMurdo v. Getter*, 298 Mass. 363, 365\.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the physician is the servant of the defendants (Stuart v. Sargent, 283 Mass. 536, 541), notwithstanding the fact that the defendants actually exercise no control over ‘the mode, manner or result of the examination of the eyes of the customer and the doctor is left free to exercise his own will . . . [and] judgment and to use his own professional skill and methods in making such examination.’ … All questions of price and business policy are determined by the defendants.”

*Kelly v. Rossi*, 395 Mass. 659, 661\u20.proposition: A rideshare company that organizes, controls, and profits from the transportation services provided by its drivers may be held liable for the negligence of those drivers in performing the company’s business.
*Kelly v. Rossi*, 395 Mass. 659, 661\u20.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a resident physician was a “public employee” of the City of Boston for immunity purposes, using common-law respondeat superior principles to assess who had the right to control her work. It does not involve rideshare companies or analogous transportation businesses, nor does it discuss corporate liability for drivers’ negligence in providing transportation services. While it reaffirms that a principal exercising direction and control over an agent can be vicariously liable, it is too far afield from the specific rideshare-liability proposition to serve as direct supporting authority for it.
*Kelly v. Rossi*, 395 Mass. 659, 661\u20.relevant_excerpt: “The legal principles that govern the determination whether the doctor was a ‘public employee’ of the city and, therefore, freed from liability to the plaintiff by G. L. c. 258, § 2, are the same as those that have determined whether an agent is a servant for whose negligent acts a principal may be liable under the common law doctrine of respondeat superior… The right to control an agent’s activities has been the guiding principle in deciding cases involving an assertion of vicarious liability against the agent’s principal.”

*Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F..raw_text: *Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F.3d 461, 466 (1st Cir. 2002) (applying Massachusetts law);
*Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F..proposition: Damages for personal injuries caused by negligence in Massachusetts may include recovery for medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F..case_name: In Re Edwin R. Smith, Debtor-Appellee. Appeal of Jerry Watson
*Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F..support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is a federal appellate bankruptcy decision concerning good faith in Chapter 13 plan confirmation. It does not involve Massachusetts law, tort damages, or any discussion of recoverable elements of personal injury damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. Accordingly, it cannot be authority for the cited Massachusetts personal-injury damages proposition.
*Grassi v. Columbus Line S.p.A.*, 286 F..relevant_excerpt: We note at the outset that the obligation of good faith is imposed on the debtor at two stages of a Chapter 13 proceeding... Before a bankruptcy court confirms a debtor’s plan under Chapter 13, it must find that the plan was filed in good faith. See 11 U.S.C. § 1325(a)(3). “The provisions of 11 U.S.C. § 1325 ensure that a Chapter 13 plan ... will be properly scrutinized by the bankruptcy court before the plan is confirmed, mitigating the danger of abuse.” In re Young, 237 F.3d 1168, 1174 (10th Cir.2001).

*Rodrigues v. Secretary of Admin. & Fin..raw_text: *Rodrigues v. Secretary of Admin. & Fin.*, 405 Mass. 697, 702 (1989).
*Rodrigues v. Secretary of Admin. & Fin..proposition: Damages for personal injuries caused by negligence in Massachusetts may include recovery for medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Rodrigues v. Secretary of Admin. & Fin..support_reasoning: The opinion is a medical malpractice and procedural damages case that discusses negligence, causation, comparative negligence, collateral source reductions, charitable immunity, and life expectancy. It does not set out or analyze the general categories of recoverable personal injury damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. Therefore it does not provide authority for the broad damages proposition stated.
